text: foreign
[Applause]
[Music]
[Music]
support engineer here at the AWS office
in Seattle today I'm going to show you
how to troubleshoot SSH issues using the
Amazon elastic compute Cloud serial
console let's get started
as an example for troubleshooting SSH
issues let's take a look at the SSH
error message permission denied and then
use the ec2 serial console to resolve
this error
with the ec2 serial console you can
access your ec2 instances serial Port so
that you can troubleshoot issues when
booting network configuration and so on
the serial console doesn't require your
instance to have any network
capabilities
with the serial console you can enter
commands to an instance as if your
keyboard and monitor are directly
attached to the instances serial Port
refer to the documentation Linked In the
associated Knowledge Center article for
more information about configuring
access to the serial console
the SSH error permission denied normally
occurs in these circumstances incorrect
private key used to connect to the ec2
instance incorrect permissions on the
SSH configuration files within the
instance incorrect user used to connect
to the ec2 instance
I have logged in to the AWS Management
console now let's navigate to the ec2
console
then select the instances from the left
navigation pane
here you can see all the running
instances in your account select the one
that's getting the error permission
denied
choose connect and navigate to the ec2
serial console option
please note by default the ec2 serial
console is not turned on for the account
choose connect
now we are connected to the ec2 serial
console for the selected instance
I have the password based OS user easy
to console for my instance and I'll use
it to log into the instance using the
ec2 serial console
please note you must set a user password
for every instance that uses the serial
console this is a one-time requirement
for each instance
this requirement applies only if you
launched your instance using an Amazon
machine image provided by AWS because by
default Ami is provided by AWS are not
configured with the password based user
if you launched your instance using an
Ami that already has the root user
account password configured you can skip
this step for setting a password based
user on the instance for configuring the
ec2 serial console
now I can access the instance using the
ec2 serial console in this example ec2
user is the username that I was using to
login using the Mac terminal change the
username according to your specific Ami
I'll first use the sudo Su ec2 user
command to switch the user from easy to
console to EC to user then I'll use the
ls hyphen LD command to make sure that
the permission of the files under the
home directory for the ec2 user are
correct
here's a list of the correct permissions
Linux home directory for example must
look like this
user's home directory for example must
look like this
dot SSH directory permission for example
must look like this
authorized Keys file permission for
example must look like this
on your local computer verify the SSH
public key I am using this command to
verify the public queue on my machine
you can use the document Link in the
associated Knowledge Center article for
other methods if you are not using a Mac
machine
update your SSH public key to the
authorized Keys file in this example
replace the example key with your SSH
public key
to correct permissions run these
commands on your ec2 instance
now I can use SSH to connect to the
instance with username easy to user with
key authentication using Mac terminal
without any issue
and now you know how to troubleshoot SSH
issues using the ec2 serial console
thanks for watching and happy cloud
computing from all of us here at AWS
[Music]
[Applause]
[Music]
thank you
[Music]
